Maggie May, 5 years old, spayed female, Pitbull/Catahoula mix, 50 pounds. She is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport to an approved adopter. Please note, she is physically located in the State of Texas. 

Maggie May was a volunteer favorite at the city shelter where she was saved off the euthanasia list and it is clear to see why - she is incredibly sweet and strikingly good looking! 

Before you think she is only just a beauty, she's got the brains and brawn to go with it. Maggie knows several commands including "sit," "down," "stay," "break (go)," "touch" and "heel." She also helps get rid of any Amazon boxes to ensure continued marital bliss. :)

She is fully house- and crate-trained but could use some additional leash training as she tends to pull - a harness or Gentle Leader head collar would be great tools here. She loves playing fetch and will do just about anything you want for a toy, so training has been made much simpler! With a toy nearby, Maggie will even allow you to clip and file down her nails with zero fuss.

Maggie May is dog friendly but is confident enough on her own to not require a companion and would actually really love having your attention all to herself.  She has met other dogs and is very excited when first meeting but does well. She gets quite vocal when being introduced to dogs - lots of grunts and whimpers and scurrying about - and some dogs may not like this overexuberance, so proper introductions should be conducted to ensure all goes well. We have found dog parks are too overstimulating for her. 

She is a solid moderate energy dog: she needs no more than a couple walks a day and she really loves them. She would love a home where she can go on sniff walks, play fetch or tug-o-war, "brain" games, or obedience training to satisfy her mental needs. Given her love of toys and fetch, Maggie could also excel at a sport or agility training! She is not bouncing off the walls but also isn't a total couch potato. When she is lounging on the couch, expect to see a toy or two (or all!) nearby. 

Maggie May has a touch of separation anxiety but it is not destructive or extreme - she whimpers as a form of self-soothing when her person is not nearby. She also paces around and nests her blankets but has never chewed up or eaten anything she shouldn't. As a general household rule, she is crated for meals and when unable to be supervised but can sleep loose in her room or with you. She has great house manners - she does not "over" bark and will alert only when startled or if someone comes to the door, she pays no mind to the vacuum and does not get into the trash.

We have no history with cats although she will see them while out walking and does not pay them any mind. She has met kids aged 2-4 years old and she LOVES them but has knocked them over with her tail wags. We typically recommend homes with kids 10 years or older, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues.

Maggie May is very affectionate with people and greets everyone as though they were a long-lost friend. She gives nose kisses and the occasional lick but finds being close enough to touch (but not actually touching) is sufficient for her needs. Maggie May is very loyal and has a strong desire to please her human. She rides well in the car and loves going on adventures (grabbing coffee) with her person. She can be possessive of her toys so these should be kept separate from other animals in the house. She would do best in a home willing to provide structure and boundaries as she thrives falling into line.

Talula, 4-year-old, spayed female, pitbull mix, 55 pounds. Talula is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Talula had a home, she had a mom, a two-legged sister and a kitty sibling but all that was lost when her family fell on hard times, and she ended up hit by a car and at the SPCA. We had hoped she would be able to return to her family but unfortunately, things did not end up that way and this sweet, perfect girl is back to looking for her furever home.

Talula is incredibly dog friendly - she lives in a foster home with 6 other dogs ranging from a 10lb chihuahua to a 106lb cane corso/pittie mix. She gets along with the males, females, old and young, bigs and smalls alike. Her play style is very playful and submissive - she enjoys chasing her foster sister around the back yard, rolls on her back when wrestling before swapping roles, and just having a grand ol' time.

Talula is fully house trained and knows how to use a doggy door. Even when first in her foster home, Talula never had an accident and adapted quickly to the routine of the house. She loves her crate and will often take a break from the chaos by napping or putting herself to bed. She enjoys taking her meals in her kennel and is a true gentlewoman, quiet as a church mouse when crated. Her foster works from home so she isn't usually kenneled for long, but she has been crated on occasion up to 9hrs.

Talula is a fantastic house guest and is not destructive - she is totally fine to be left alone unsupervised and has yet to get into anything she shouldn't. She enjoys the opportunity to sleep loose (sometimes she doesn't want to, instead choosing her kennel) and is a perfect bed-guest too. She finds a spot near the foot of the bed and stays there.

Talula walks well on a leash and is non-reactive when encountering other dogs or strangers; she rides well in a car; and of course, enjoys plushy toys or snack time. Her only "flaws" appear to be a penchant for digging holes and immediately rolling around in the freshly tilled dirt; being an epic snorer; and being timid around men. She still barks at her foster dad and brother-in-law, even after living with them for nearly two months. She will make pains to avoid going by them, taking the long way around to the back door or waiting to enter the house until they've moved on. 

Overall, Talula is docile and so even keeled that it speaks volumes of the hardships her adoptive home must have been going through that they would not come back for her. We would love for her next chapter to be the last time she is unsettled. She is the most cuddly, sweet and affectionate girl there is, and she deserves a home that is willing to reciprocate that love. She doesn't need an overly active house - a backyard to run around in or a couple walks a day are plenty to satisfy her physical demands. She would love having a sibling of the two- and four-legged variety, or plenty of opportunities for doggy day care, play dates, or the dog park to socialize.

Talula has lived with toddlers and cats before but does not currently live with either. In general, we recommend homes with kids over the age of 10yrs or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues.

Sunny, 5 years old, neutered male, Pitbull mix, 98 lbs. He is in a foster home in Houston, Texas and can transport to an approved adopter. 

He is a an energetic boy who loves his people! He is very eager to please and has been living with one of our trainers. He has learned many basic commands: sit, down, stay and place. He is both crate and housetrained. He is treat motivated. 

Sunny has met a lot of different dogs in the time we've had him in rescue. We have found he does best with a well balanced dog. He can be forward when initially meeting another dog and likes to run when playing. Another dog who will disengage is the best match for our guy. He would also do wonderful as an only dog. 

He seems curious about cats in the neighborhood, but have no history with cats inside the home. We have no history with kids. Due to his wiggly body, we recommend a home with kids 12 years and older. 

Sunny walks well on leash. When he sees another dog he will pull because he wants to say hi. He is easy to redirect. For the most part he walks a little in front with little pulling. He is housebroken. He enjoys being his crate with the door open. 

He is food motivated. He loves to chew on toys and bones. We would describe him as moderate energy. His current foster takes him on a walk daily and he really enjoys the exercise. 

He is very smart and eager to please. He likes to be close to his human when you are home. We think he would do best with someone who was home more than they were away. He has been left out in the house unsupervised and will find things on the counters if left out.  He is very friendly and loves to cuddle.

Star, 8 months old (estimated DOB August 2023), spayed female, Retriever/Dane mix, currently weighs 50 pounds, expected to be a large size when full grown. She is physically located in a foster home in San Antonio, TEXAS and can transport out of State once an adopter is approved. 

We saw someone post about Star and her friend after they were picked up by Animal Control and taken to the county shelter. Their owner had been without a home and was arrested which led to them being picked up. Due to overcrowding, Star was scheduled for euthanasia. We are thankful a foster home came forward to save her precious life. 

Since being in foster care, Star has mastered crate training. She goes in her crate and is pretty quiet overall. She is fully housebroken and walks really well on leash. 

Star is a typical puppy with that zest for life and curious view of the world. She is walking well on leash. She is very friendly and greets everyone with a tail wag. She will jump up in a friendly manner which her foster mom has been working on. She would greatly benefit from a home who will invest energy into providing her a foundation, consistency and lots of love. 

She has been in a home with a cat. She has tried to make friends by running after him. We think she is eager to make friends. If you have a cat who can set boundaries with a dog, we think she would do great. 

Star shares a home with an older dog. She has learned to respect boundaries and picks up on ques. She has met other dogs outside of the house and brings all of that fun puppy energy. She loves to play, chase and run around. We think she would do wonderful with a dog who wants to play. She would do okay as an only dog with ways to socialize her with other dogs. She has discovered toys and really likes dismantling the squeakers. 

We have no history with kids and recommend a home with kids who respect and understand animal boundaries. 

Star is eager to learn and please. She rides well in the car and loves to be around people. For puppies this age, someone needs to be home more than they are away. We would like to see another dog in the home to continue her healthy socialization with other dogs. 

Star's foster mom tells us that she really is such a lover. She has wonderful house manners. She will run and have zoomies in the backyard. She rides well in the car and is so excited about life.

Hi I'm Maximus, or Max for short. They say I'm a fantastic good boy and I'm ready for a real home. I was abandoned in a neighborhood here in San Antonio, Texas.  I was scared and had no idea why my owner left me here.  I wonder the area and got lucky as there was a wonderful man that gave me a temporary home.  He has a dog just like me and we get along great.  I love the neighborhood kids and he is helping me walk calmly on a leash.  

I'm friendly with people, great with other dogs, and only about a year old. 

I'm good in the car and good on leash but working on pulling a bit. I'm housetrained so I know to use the potty outside!

MEET BEAUTIFUL BELLA!

Bella is a 10mo old (born June 2023) spayed female black labrador, weighing 54 lbs, and currently is in a foster home in HOUSTON TX. She can be transported out of state to an approved adopter. 

Bella's rescue story is unlike many others: a family found a wandering loose dog in their neighborhood and took her in...only to soon find out she was pregnant. That pregnant mama gave birth to THIRTEEN puppies and this amazing family did their very best to give all 14 dogs what they needed - physically, mentally and emotionally. Thankfully, the family reached out to rescues and we were able to intake several, splitting the puppies amongst a few local rescues.

Bella was raised with her 12 siblings and absolutely adores playing with other dogs. She knows when other dogs want to stop playing, doesn't have issues with high energy dogs, and lights up when she has doggy playmates. Another dog in the home would be great to help grow confidence and bring her out of her shell. She's still learning how to play with other dogs - she can play a little rough, but has started laying down and pawing the other dog to get her to play. 

Bella is very puppy-like: she likes to chase balls and toys when you throw them for her (and will sometimes bring them back). She takes off for the toys running and bouncing, leaping the whole way to the toy and when she gets to it, she bats at it like she's a cat. It's really funny to see!

Bella is excellent in the home. She's still young so she's had the occasional accident, but she gets the hang of a routine quickly and her foster has noted a significant improvement. Bella is crate trained and does really, really well - she takes her meals and sleeps in the kennel, and has spent up to 8hrs crated while her foster is at work. She takes comfort in her "room" and will go to the crate when you tell her without a single bit of fuss.

Bella does need a bit of work on the leash but overall has good manners, such that her mom has been able to take her for runs. She does best with some slack on the leash and may benefit from a Gentle Leader head collar or a "no pull" harness, especially if there is a good smell to be sniffed. Bella is curious when she sees another dog when she is on a leash - she notices them and acts like she wants to play. 

She's an active young lady and overall sweet, curious and silly just as you'd expect. She'd love a yard at her new home to run around, and would love to ride in your car for a trip to the park. She does great in the car, curling up and snoozing until she's reached her destination.

Once she is comfortable with you, she loves to get attention and follow you around the house, but is not stuck to you. She can be timid at first but warms up and is quite cuddly and affectionate, she likes to give kisses and be around people.  She is very sweet and loving! 

An ideal home for Bella has doggy siblings and an active life style. She would love to spend the rest of her days getting lots of love from her family and playing in a yard with other dogs. Bella would love a patient adoptive home that is willing to help her navigate this big world and have lots of fun along the way. 

She does well with gentle correction and redirection, but is still young and learning new interactions with people. She does best with meeting strangers outside of the house before they come inside where she feels safe. We suggest a home with older children that will respect her boundaries when she communicates her discomfort. She has been in a home with a child as young as 10 yrs and did well. We have no history with cats.

description:
******Please note, once completing the initial screen you will be connected with the placement for a video chat. If you are not able to accept a dog until a specific time period, please apply at that time************

If someone other than yourself is part of the decision making process, please make sure you have spoken with them and they are on board. We really do not want to waste anyone's time if you are not serious about adopting this dog.

Lilly, 6.5 years old, spayed female, plot hound/pitbull Terrier mix, 65 pounds. She is located in HOUSTON, TEXAS and can transport out of State to an approved adopter. You will be connected to her foster home for a video chat once screened. 

Lilly is the goofiest, silliest, sweetest and most deserving girl there is in all the land. Every thing is a new experience for her and even if it isn’t, she makes you feel like it is because she’s just that grateful to be with you. She is magnetic and is hard to forget, and is just so happy.

She rides like a champ in the car, laying back and snoozing until arriving at her destination.  She’s potty trained and only had a few accidents in the house, mostly a result of nerves from being in a new place and having too much fun playing outside with her doggy foster siblings.  Once she got a hang of our routine and figured out the doggy door, she never had another accident. 

She is not food or toy aggressive and can happily roam free in the house, keeping out of anything she shouldn’t get into.  She is crate trained but knows well how to bust out of them!  She likes grazing on her food throughout the day and will occasionally shred a plushy toy, but who’s never done that before??

She loves simple things: a spoon of peanut butter, ice, frozen watermelon, hiding under the bed to sleep, a soft doggy bed, COUCH TIME, and oh does she love sleeping in the bed with you! She doesn’t love baths but she loves how she feels afterward, so she resigns herself to that necessary evil.  She snores and snorts, grunts and groans, and bugs her eyes out.  She’s quite the character and we love having her in the house.  

She is not afraid of men or children, other dogs, loud (she sleeps through the vacuum) or strange noises.  She rarely barks.  She’s a good low/moderate level energy - she likes to play and can definitely have spurts of energy but once given the chance to work the zoomies out, she is most content to sleep away the day.  

She got along well with the four dogs - all large males. Initially we noticed some barrier reactivity while she was in her crate but this was resolved by moving her to a private room and then slowly introducing her to the dogs in the house.  She did great! She doesn’t like dogs getting up in her face and will grumble or growl but she never initiated a squabble.  She will engage in play or she will just follow her friends around and things out. We think she do great with another dog or would be great by herself. She really loves the company of her people. 

We would not recommend her for any house with very young children or people unsteady on their feet - she’s still learning some basic manners and will often run at you before using your chest as a springboard to twirl in the air - basically, she’s Simone Biles! We have no history with cats.

Lilly deserves all the good things because she herself is a good thing...she has a lot to make up for and she is eager to get going! If you haven't already fallen in love with her, wait until you see her potbelly...it's legendary. :)

breeds_label: Pit Bull Terrier & Yellow Labrador Retriever Mix
description:
******Please note, once completing the initial screen you will be connected with the placement for a video chat. Transports run every few weeks and we will have the dog on the next available transport once approved. If you are not able to accept a dog until a specific time period, please apply at that time************

We are a volunteer run rescue and donate our time to these dogs. IF you are not serious about moving forward in our adoption process, please do not apply. If someone other than yourself is part of the decision making process, please make sure you have spoken with them and they are on board. We really do not want to waste anyone's time if you are not serious about adopting this dog.

Freddie, 5 years old, neutered male, Pitbull/lab mix, 53 pounds. Freddie is in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of State once an adopter is approved. You will have an opportunity to video chat to "meet" him virtually. 

Freddie has dashingly handsome good looks and a set of button ears any show dog would kill for. When he hears something interesting, he tilts his head and looks at you with these wide soft brown eyes. He has a gorgeous smile and a set of 8-pack abs that will make you giggle and then run to the gym to get your own. Our most favorite thing about him, though, are a series of cowlicks which line his chest, lower waist and butt cheeks. You could get lost in those swirls.

Freddie is a naturally inquisitive and inherently brave boy who just isn’t fully confident he can do all of the things he wants to attempt, so he looks to his person for reassurance and to calm his nerves. While we have no history
of his life as a pup or before he came to the shelter, we believe the cause for his anxiety really rests in under-socialization. When exposed to new things, places and people, Freddie can be nervous but he wants to push through and just needs the encouragement to do so. Freddie has come so far since being rescued last year and placed into foster care, and he continues to improve every day.

He is a perfect gentleman on a leash, is crate and house trained, and people and dog friendly - although he can be stiff when meeting large dogs. He would do best with dogs who are submissive or willing to be submissive, as this stiffness can come read like he is trying to assert himself (which he isn't). He would not do well with a dog who is in your face hyper, that's just too much for him.

Freddie likes to go on walks and loves any sort of hard, chew toy. He gets extremely playful when given the opportunity to play with squishy toys, thrashing his head, galloping and whining. He loves to play tug-of-war and likes water bottles filled with rocks - he’s a man of simple pleasures. He can be mischievous around wayward shoes or soft fluffy items, but that seems to be a crime of convenience.

Freddie absolutely loves routine and structure, and would be best served by someone who will allow him a week or two to acclimate to his new environment, and to settle in and learn the ropes. With consistency, Freddie bonds tightly to his person and seeks out their company. He appreciates knowing when and who will let him out, feed him, and give him the love he so desperately deserves. He will often put himself to bed when he is overstimulated and needs a break.

His normal day includes a half/mile walk morning and night with a few potty breaks in between as able, and a healthy dose of one-on-one time for affection and some exposure training. He has gone 10hrs between potty breaks without incident. Freddie has only had one accident throughout his time with us and that was when he first came here. Outside of that, Freddie has not had an accident in the house.

He makes an excellent couch partner with current TV favorites being any of the British Bake Off series, dramas, or legal thrillers. Freddie loves listening to soothing music at night and would be an excellent companion for a single or older person who has the ability to shower him with time and attention. His energy level is best described as low to moderate, as he doesn’t need very long walks to get his energy out, and he’s not bouncing off the walls if he doesn’t get those walks. 

He can be a jumper so we would recommend children over the age of 10.
He can absolutely be an only dog, although he’d thrive in a home with other canine companions. When Freddy sees other dogs, he gets very excited and likes to bark and play bow at them through the barrier.

In the time he has been in our house as a foster, Freddie has learned to be in a crate during the day and occasionally at night, and to ignore loud or scary sounds like lawnmowers, buses, etc. Freddy’s anxiety manifests itself as licking, heavy panting, and the occasional whimpering; he is not destructive to house or home. He knows basic commands and is extremely food motivated, so additional training should be easy and would really help him have a positive outlet for his anxiety. We’ve found calming chews, soft music at night, positive reinforcement,
and a set schedule are the tools Freddie requires to be the brave boy he is.

Gus, 2yr old neutered male, pit bull mix, 75 pounds. Gus is in a foster home in San Antonio, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Gus is a friendly, happy and wiggly little piggy who enjoys running around the backyard or going on walks. He is still a young guy and would make an incredible adventure buddy for an active, on-the-go type of home. His most favorite thing in the world is water and he would be ever so thrilled to have a pool, lake or boat of his own to be closer to it.

Gus has been fostered in a home with other dogs and does best with one who is well balanced. He can be very forward in his playstyle so a dog who is neutral would be best suited, as his eagerness can tip the scales otherwise. He likes wrestling and running around with other dogs, and prefers an active canine sibling to a layabout. He does not have to be the only dog but would certainly welcome being the center of your world if you deemed it necessary.

Gus does not currently - but did formerly - live with younger kids, aged 2-8yrs and did well overall but due to his energy and occasional habit of jumping and being a bit mouthy, we would recommend a home with kids over the age of 10yrs. No matter the age, we generally recommend a home with kids who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. We have no direct history with cats but his foster notes he seems to ignore them while on walks.

As a young lad, Gus needs some improvement on his leash skills as he does tend to pull and will get overly excited when another dog comes into his line of vision. We have found a "no pull" harness or Gentle Leader head collar work well to limit his pulling and thankfully, he generally sticks to one side while walking. He finds himself one with nature on walks and will chase butterflies or follow bugs crawling along the sidewalk.

Gus is very smart and trainable, and is fully house and crate trained. He has been allowed to stay loose in the house while unsupervised for short periods of time but is overall crated when no one is home. He's very calm and peaceful in his kennel, and enjoys eating his meals in there.

When he gets too excited, Gus will jump up and play bite but his fosters have been correcting this by ignoring him or ending play until he settles down. He is easily redirectable and his foster says does best with a toy in his mouth while getting pets. Unsurprisingly, he's often found with a ball in his mouth - ready in case you want to play a quick game of fetch...his second favorite activity.

Gus absolutely loves people and play time. He's friendly but not overly cuddly and enjoys sitting on the couch with his head on the pillow. He does fantastic when meeting new people and takes treats very gently. His ideal home would be with someone willing to invest time in basic obedience and who will provide structure and routine, he needs a positive outlet for his moderate energy or he will get bored. He enjoys a squeaky toy or benebone, chasing the water hose with a high pitched bark before retreating inside to nap on the couch.

Major Aster, 1 years old, neutered male, black mouth cur/ Staffordshire Terrier mix, 55 pounds. Major is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Major and his two brothers were saved from an overcrowded shelter in San Antonio. They have been residing in the same foster home. One of the brothers has been adopted and Major is patiently waiting his turn! 

Smart Major- Major is good-natured and sweet. He is the most easy going and mellow of the trio. He matches the energy of other dogs, so if they want to romp around he's happy to do so. If not, he will just quietly walk around.  He has had some playtime with a Shitzu puppy and was very sweet with her. He would play bow and roll around on the floor to be at her level. 

He is SMART- he picked up on "sit" within minutes and has "stay" and "no speak" almost down. He's very intuitive and seems to really understand what you want from him when he's in a focused mood. He is very treat motivated for training. He is very loyal and will occasionally lean against your leg for some pets before running off to play more. 

He lives in a foster home with cats but we're not sure if he's cat friendly just yet. He barks and wants to chase the cats when he sees them, and the cats run away before they actually encounter one another. The cats and Major are kept separated by baby gates.

Major also shares a home with a 9 year old child and LOVES her. They have become good friends.  He has a great temperament and seems very intuitive about his size and appropriate behavior. We think he would do great around any ages of children. We always recommend a home with kids who understand and respect animal boundaries. 

Major likes to be in front and will sometimes pull on leash.  He likes to sniff things and explore, so often will cross in front, go around or behind, step down into the street or pull. He is crate trained and house broken.  

Major is a good-natured sweetheart. He loves balls and his Kong treat toy, especially when filled with peanut butter.  He is VERY loyal, intuitive and smart and loves tummy rubs ?

Major would thrive in an active home. He loves to go on walks and we think with some guidance would make a really great running buddy. His forever home would be understanding he is a young dog who needs structure and consistency.

Snowy Sasha, 8 month old, spayed female pit bull mix, 48pounds. Snowy is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

From what her rescuers know of Snowy’s existence – Snowy spent most of her young life on a short chain wearing a heavy leather harness without socialization. Snowy is catching up on so many puppy experiences and critical life stages she was robbed of while being isolated at such a young age. All considered, Snowy is doing well with learning how to be a part of a pack, trust humans and live indoors.

Snowy Sasha plays vigorously (hard), she enjoys playing chase & tackle and tug of war with her foster siblings, and will herd her siblings biting and chewing at their feet during play.  Snowy plays with dogs of all sizes (large, medium, and small while in her foster home ranging from an 80 lb. Staffordshire Terrier, 45lb Black mouth Cur, 30 lb. Shepard mix to a 12 lb. Chiweenie) and is learning how to be a part of a pack. She is learning to pick up and read cues from her playmates and when to playing. 

As she's had nearly no socialization to date, Snowy requires slow, supervised introductions but once she is introduced properly, she is comfortable and will play well with other dogs. Snowy does fine on a leash - she's not all over the place, walks calmly, and pulls only a moderate bit. Her foster mom is working on her leash skills, so she has not had a great deal of exposure to other dogs who are on a leash in public settings but notes that Snowy becomes reactive when she sees other dogs on a leash, barking loudly. 

We have not introduced her to cats yet, but she has met older kids (12-16 years old) with no issues at all. Based on her energy level, we believe she would be okay with small children. It is important no matter how old the kids in a home are that they understand and respect animal behavior cues.  

Snowy is house broken and her foster is working to train her to alert using door bells. She is crated when unable to be supervised and while sleeping at night. When her foster is home working, Snowy is left unattended in the kitchen and does fine with “puppy-proofing” of the room since she's still in that puppy exploring/chewing phase. 

Snowy has displayed some resource guarding around food, treats and bones so she does best when fed separately in her kennel or a different room. When her fellow foster pup attempts to take her antler or cow hoof while she is actively chewing on it, she will show her teeth and give a low growl.

A moderately active home would suit her energy level. Snowy plays vigorously with other dogs and enjoys a good daily walk but calms down easily and naps throughout the day. Snowy’s peak playful times are when she wakes up early in the morning and evening before bed. She looooves to play with stuffed toys with squeakers in them and playing tug with the other dogs, especially the bungie rope toy hung in her backyard. 

She will benefit from another dog of similar size, age and energy level to play with or regular exposure to a play group (doggy day care) to continue her positive socialization. Being around humans is new to Snowy, she's learning how to trust and once she feels comfortable, she's very affectionate and eager to please. She enjoys showing and receiving affection and being near her humans. Gentle encouragement go a long way for Snowy when meeting strangers and she would love a patient, understanding and reassuring adopter to call Mom/Dad.

Snowy is a “diamond in the rough” who will thrive in a home with forever parents who are patient and willing to continue train her. Forever parents who are experienced dog owners, even Staffie/Pittie breed experience with a familiarity of the breed quirks.

Slow introductions take place over one to two weeks at least. The first week, the new pet should be contained to a separate room in a kennel and given time to decompress. Once acclimated to their new environment, the pets are allowed to pass by one another's kennels and watched for reaction. After another day or two of successful kennel passes, the pets can begin meeting on opposite sides of a baby gate or other barrier before progressing to supervised and leashed interactions. Assuming all has gone smoothly to this point, pets can be allowed off leash to interact. Another great way to "slow" intro a dog is through parallel walks on opposite sides of a street or with one dog far ahead of the other, slowly meeting until side-by-side. It is important potential adopters give their new family member time to adjust, as it is a big change for these pets.

Roux, 2yr old spayed female, pitbull mix, 53 pounds. Roux is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Roux is an excitable, energetic gal who loves to play hard. She likes to chase and herd her canine friends, nipping at their legs and neck when excited. She lives in a foster home with a large breed dog and would do best with another dog of her same size and energy level/play style. An older or smaller dog would not be the ideal match for this young spitfire. 

Roux is mostly non-reactive toward other dogs but will bark and pull toward them when encountered on her walks - she's super eager to go say hi and play, but she does not bark nor is she aggressive in her excitement. She has decent leash manners but when she catches a scent she wants to see through, Roux can pull rather hard. Her foster is working with her and in general, we find harnesses or Gentle Leader head collars to work well at controlling unwanted leash behaviors.

Roux has been around younger kids at her neighborhood park but does not spend much time nor does she live with them. She behaved sweetly with a toddler who approached her in the park but since she's an eager beaver, we would recommend an adoptive home with kids over the age of 8yrs. 

Roux is cat friendly...to an extent. She lives in a foster home with cats and enjoys the company of the youngest cat, sleeping nearby when they are both settled. Like any older sister, though, when Roux gets overstimulated and she sees him move - she does like to chase after him. She's more curious than anything but her foster notes it depends a lot on her energy level at the time.

Roux is working on her house manners: learning to settle and what an acceptable inside energy level is, and perfecting her potty training. She drinks a lot of water (gotta stay hydrated with all that play!) so she does pee a lot and is let out every 2-3 hours when her foster is home. Nevertheless, Roux has had a few accidents in the house.

She is crated during the day and has never had an accident in the crate. She’s ok in the crate but will cry in the mornings when she hears that people are up. She has serious FOMO. She always wants to be inside or out of the crate with her people. She is always crated when unsupervised as she finds things to destroy. Puppy behavior.

Roux has not demonstrated any food aggression or resource guarding, but she does enjoy stealing her foster sibling's toys and is an avid toy destroyer. Roux LOVES to play. She’ll fetch, tug, and likes chew bones. She is very sweet and cuddly and tries to sit in your lap. 

Roux would be happiest in a home with active people or people that would work her - long walks/runs, hikes, sniff spots, doggy day care or parks, and even obedience or agility training. She can jump and is very strong, and she has a herding drive that can be fun if used correctly. She’d appreciate a similar energy level dog companion but would be fine as an only dog as long as the owners were active. She enjoys being busy and is curious to always be on the lookout for something to get into.

Charley, 5 year old, neutered male, plott hound/pit bull mix, 50 lbs. Charley is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an adopter is approved! 

He's a really amiable guy and has been in playgroups of up to 4 dogs, male and female with much success. He responds well to dogs when initially meeting them, very curious and enthusiastic to be friends. Charley is very enthusiastic about playing with the dogs and is always down for a romp. He has a lot of energy when he plays, and he enjoys going to the apartment complex's dog park for larger dogs. 

Charley doesn't have a prey drive so he may be okay with cats or small animals but we do not have any history or previous experiences with him meeting cats. Charley has been around kids and would be best for a home with kids over the age of 12yrs. He's energetic and may inadvertently knock over a small toddler but dreams of having a two-legged sibling to chase him around or take him on walks.

Charley lives in an apartment and has been a model guest since arriving - he's not climbed on furniture, broken or chewed anything he shouldn't, and is house and crate trained. His foster works away from home and he is content by himself for 7hrs or more per day, but he does get antsy when his foster leaves his line of sight, pacing and whining until he comes back. 

Charley may take a couple weeks to settle into a routine but once he's established the gameplan and where he falls in line, he will exceed expectations. He is very food motivated so training is made that much simpler! He also responds very well to gentle correction and excels with stability & routine. Short "time outs" and the leash are high value corrections for him - he doesn't need a strong hand to make an impression.

Charley goes on frequent walks to get out his energy and is a gentleman on the leash but will get excited and pull towards other dogs that pass by. He is moderate to high energy (a 5-6 out of 10) and thrives with extra play time once or so a day. He would love to join in on adventures, whether that be running, walking, hikes or car rides - he is ready! 

Through it all, Charley does relax in the house and loves to cuddle, he's very sweet and affectionate. He is an overall happy dog who seeks attention and love - he's good natured and goofy, even a bit clumsy! He loves to ride in the car and just wants to be with his people. Charley *loves* nylabones, pig ears/bully sticks or cheese.

Theodore is a 2 YR old, 45 lb, neutered male Staffordshire mix, who is currently being fostered in Houston, TX. He can be transported to an approved adopter. 

Theodore is a loving, calm dog who does well with people and dogs! He loves to cuddle his foster family and naps with his foster dog sibling on the couch during the day. He enjoys meeting strangers and is calm and sweet while he's being pet. He has a playful energy level and loves to romp around with his toys. 

Theodore does well with other dogs! He has a zealous play style and sometimes can be a little too much for some dogs. He often tries to engage is foster sibling in play. He does well with dogs of various sizes. He would love to have a doggy sibling to play with but would do fine in a home on his own. No food aggression has been observed with either humans or other dogs. 

Theodore enjoys playing with toys and sometimes can mistake a household item for his own. He does well when redirected from the item. He has had a few accidents in the home, but is doing better in his training. Theodore is crated at night and when alone, and does well in the crate. When on leash, Theodore does not react to other dogs or people and walks calmly next to his foster mom. Sometimes he likes to take breaks on walks, so he doesn't need a daily adventure. Just a stroll or two a day is sufficient for this guy!

We believe that Theodore's small to medium size and calm temperament make him ideal for homes with children of many ages. He currently does not live with children. 

Theodore would thrive in almost any home. He is still working on some of his training, but he aims to please and he progresses every day in his foster home.

Penelope, 4 year old spayed female, Rottweiler/labrador mix, 57 pounds. Penelope is in a foster home in San Antonio, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Penelope is as sweet as you would expect a lady to be - she loves showing you her belly and play bows to friends, and is very submissive. 

She lives in a foster home with a large senior female dog and she really enjoys engaging her in play. She has a silly habit of chomping at the air when she's feeling goofy and it's quite endearing, as if she needed any more charm!

She has never shown any signs of aggression or standoffishness while in foster care to humans or dogs alike. She is playful but can be mellow and a couch potato, and she LOVES to follow you around. She's a built in best friend and guide for navigating your own house!

She loves toys and will bring one to you when you come home from work, proud of all the things she now gets to call her own. She is a people pleaser and thrives on praise and affection.

We have no history with small dogs, cats or kids but generally do not expect there to be any issues with her behavior. As a standard rule, we recommend homes with kids over the age of 10yrs or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues.

Penelope is getting better on her leash when going for walks. She loves a schedule and is fed in her kennel and let her out when the resident dog is done eating. Penelope is a great environmental steward and always makes sure that her foster sister ate all her food! She is crate trained and potty trained. 

She would do best in a home with another dog that has the same energy as her. Penelope could also be an only dog if her adopters enjoy taking time to play with her and spend time with her. She would do best with a yard so she can run around as she loves to show you her zoomies. 

Penelope is the sweetest dog and deserves a home where she could be for the rest of her days! Her name definitely suits her sweet personality.

Krayola is a spayed female, weights 42 lbs, and is a 1 YR old, Lab/Staffordshire mix who is currently in a foster home in Houston, TX. She can be transported to an approved adopter. 

MEET KRAYOLA

Krayola will bring color into your life! She's an affectionate girl with lots of playful energy who is looking for her next big adventure. She loves the outdoors and she's active so a home that can provide the excitement she's craving would be best. She loves new people and doesn't know a stranger. 

In the home, Krayola is a loyal, fun girl. She loves to play with plushies and chew on bones. She's crated when her foster family is not home and at night and does well. She's young so she's had a few accidents in the short time she's been in the foster home but she's working on it! She loves to cuddle her foster family after a good game of chase in the yard. She's also learning tricks like sitting and waiting for her meals. 

Krayola is very dog friendly and is always looking to play. She would love a doggy sibling to play with. She's always trying to entice the dogs in the home but they are disinterested. The other dogs in the home are 10 and 40 lbs and she's friendly with both and can pick up when they don't want to play. Krayola wants a friend! She has shown no aggression with other dogs. She is fed separately as a rule, but hasn't shown aggression around toys, bones, or treats. On leash, she loves seeing other dogs and people but doesn't bark as they pass. She can pull a bit when she smells something good but also can walk calmly on walks. 

Krayola has not been around cats or children. We think a home with older children would be best as she's very rambunctious and thinks everyone plays with her same enthusiasm. So, she may knock over younger kids when she's excited.

An ideal home for Krayola would be an active one where her family is excited to engage with her, continue her training and play. She'd love a doggy sibling or two. Krayola is the new adventure pup you've been waiting for!

Arrielle, 2 years old, spayed female, pitbull mix, 35 pounds. Arrielle is in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Arrielle was saved from the local high kill shelter in Houston and is now ready to be part of your world! She has not met many dogs in her home since she's still in quarantine but in the brief, supervised interactions she's had, she has not shown any signs of concern. That said, Arrielle does tend to favor some dogs more than others, and would do best with slow, proper introductions.

Slow introductions look like a week or two separated from other dogs in the home, followed by interactions through a barrier (kennel, x-pen, baby gate), then supervised encounters while on a leash, and finally loose co-mingling. This process may take one to two weeks, maybe more. Another great tactic to ensure proper introductions are walks in a neutral space at a distance before slowing bringing the dogs closer and closer together until they're side by side.

We have no history with cats or children, and based upon her behavior thus far, would recommend homes with older children. As a general rule, we typically recommend homes with kids over the age of 10yrs, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. 

Arrielle has impeccable house manners and is fully house broken, crate trained and fantastic on a leash. She walks calmly next to you and doesn't pull unless something catches her attention. Gentle redirection works wonders with this gal, and she quickly gets back on track. She is very comfortable in her kennel and feels safe in there, taking her meals and treats in the crate. She has not yet been trusted loose in the house while unsupervised but her foster doesn't think this would be an issue because she's yet to show any signs of anxiety or destructive nature.

Arrielle is a moderate energy girl and does not require an active home. She is easy going and loves to follow your lead. Normal short walks and showing her love and affection are all she needs to be set for life. She lives for one-on-one attention and enjoys chewing on a bone while curled up next to you. Arrielle thrives on routine - she enjoys knowing her meals are at a set time, walks are consistent, and the structure that comes with a workday.

She can be a bit apprehensive when meeting a new person, barking a bit but with slow introductions, she warms up and will approach for pets and cuddles. Once she has latched on to you, she is a very sweet, highly affectionate girl who loves pets and is quite treat motivated. She's remarkably intelligent and highly trainable. She is looking for direction and loves to show you that she is capable of achieving the given task. She will sit for treats and listens to verbal cues. Overall, she is an amazing and well-balanced sweet girl.

Sheya, 1.5 year old, spayed female, German Shepherd mix, 50 pounds. Sheya is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Sheya is a queen and commands respect but is willing to give it back too. She has been around many other dogs ranging in size from extra large - Anatolian and German Shepherd males, to large Rottweiler females, and those in between. She makes herself known and can play rough, but does not always pick up on cues from the other dogs. Overall though, she and her foster siblings play well together, watching and chasing squirrels, and other "assigned jobs." With males in particular, Sheya falls into a pack role with ease.

We have no history with cats, but Sheya has been around older children (aged 8 and 15) with success. She does still nip and can be bossy, so we would advise homes with kids over the age of 10yrs, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. 

Sheya has a guard mentality and takes her job seriously, protecting her own in their space. When outsiders dare intrude on her turf, she is the world's best alarm system. She does best meeting new people outside the home or in slow doses with her person around to assure her it is okay. Once she has grown accustomed to you, Sheya is a lovey dovey cuddle machine and enjoys close proximity to you. She loves to the end of the earth and bonds tightly.

Sheya is higher energy than she is couch potato and is quite athletic. In her first foster home, she would go on 3+ mile walks several times a day and now, she has the run of a large backyard and active foster siblings to chase her about. She knows how to jump over crates or gates.

Sheya is nearly fully house trained and may have accidents while adjusting to a new routine. She does alert when she needs to go outside but she does best on a strict schedule of breaks. Sheya's current routine is an early morning potty as soon as she wakes up, a break in the mid-day and again after her pawrents get home from work; about an hour after dinner, she is let back outside to potty and roam before a final break before bed.

Sheya is crate trained and will go in willingly, although she is trusted to be left loose in her own space. She sleeps loose on a doggy bed and has not been destructive. Sheya knows manners - she sits when you tell her to and is learning to wait for food, not jump, and to settle down. She's learned the commands "easy" and "calm down." She is incredibly intelligent and listens to instruction well, but does try testing the boundaries of what is allowed. 

Sheya should be fed separately from other dogs as she has previously exhibited food aggression around other dogs. She has no issues with humans picking up or taking away food, treats or toys though. Treats and toys in shared/communal spaces are generally limited as a rule of the foster. Through a lot of hard work with her foster, Sheya has been able to relax and accept treats nearby her siblings.

Sheya's ideal home would be with a shepherd/working breed experienced owner - someone willing to put in the work to earn her trust and assert structure and obedience. She has so many of the wonderful shepherd qualities that endear the breed to their people but is plagued by the anxiety and high-strung personality that makes their ownership a (rewarding) challenge. She has demonstrated a lot of growth in the time she's been in foster but will require patience and diligent attention to training. 

If you thought you always wanted a shepherd because you love everything about them then she may be perfect for you!

***Listed BREED and AGE - We are taking our best guess & recommendations from our veterinarian on age, breed and size when fully grown. We rarely know a dog's exact age nor are we able to tell the true or full breed mix of dogs as our information is limited most of the time. ***

Meet the "G" litter. This litter of puppies was born at the county shelter to mom Greenley. A wonderful family saved them from being euthanized (yes, they are euthanizing moms & puppies for space at many shelters in Texas). 

Gil (Gilbert), 10 months (estimated DOB 3/21/23), male, Pitbull mix, estimated medium size dog when full grown. He weighs about 50 pounds currently. He is in a foster home physically located in Houston, Texas and is able to transport from Texas to an approved adopter. He is the last of his litter to be adopted, so we are hoping his family is looking for him! 

Gil is the most playful of the group. He shares a home with his mom and other dogs. His foster mom works at a doggy daycare and he's been able to go a few days a week. He LOVES playing with all the other dogs. He has really great manners. We would love to see him in a home with another dog to continue his positive socialization. If no other dog, please indicate how he will socialize with other dogs. 

He is potty trained and does well when crated. He is still working on his leash skills. He is curious and loves adventures. He rides well in the car and enjoys pup cups. He likes to play in water, with toys and chasing balls. He is energetic, but after some play crashes out for awhile. He is friendly and always ready for whatever you adventure you have in mind. 

We have no history with cats or kids and recommend a home with kids who respect and understand animal boundaries. 


For puppies this age, someone needs to be home more than they are away as crating them for long periods of time is not conducive for their developmental needs. If you work outside of the home for 6 hours or more, please specify on the application who will be with the puppy during the time you are away.

Essie, 1.5 years old, spayed female, Shepherd mix, 45 pounds. She is in a foster home in San Antonio, TEXAS and can transport out of State once an adopter is approved! 

If you have checked out any of our other dogs profiles, you have probably seem so many of them are saved from euthanasia at county shelters in Texas. Essie's story begins the same way. We happened to be scrolling on Facebook, when we saw a volunteer post about her friend "Comet." We reached out to the shelter not knowing he also was kenneled with Essie. The shelter gave us 10 minutes to decide if we could help both of them, as they were already in the pre-euthanasia room. We are really so grateful we found foster homes to save their lives. 

 She has met other dog and had another foster temporarily stay with her. She is very friendly and polite with other dogs. If another dog engages her, she will play and is gentle in her style. She tends to read the energy of the other dog very well. When passing other dogs on leash, she is friendly. We think she would do great with another dog or would be okay as the only pet. 

She is currently being fostered in an apartment setting. She does have zoomies occasionally and it appears when walking on leash she would like to move more. We think she would really enjoy a yard of her own. This is not required as she seems to do fine in her current setting. If no yard, she will need daily physical outlets. 

We have no history with cats or kids. We recommend a home with kids 8 years and older who understand and respect animal boundaries. 

Essie does pretty well on the leash. She can be a little all over the place and can be a little jumpy at loud noises. She is fully housebroken and does very well in the crate. She loves food and her chew toys. She is crated when unsupervised as her foster mom has caught her chewing on a few household items. 

She can be nervous when meeting new people. She is looking for a family who will be patient with her as she acclimates to a new environment. Although a dog is not required in the home, we do think a four legged friend helps her feel comfortable quicker. There are no current pets in her foster home, so we do know she is okay as the only pet. 

As she opens up, she really loves pets and to be close to you. She is really a very sweet girl. We hope that in time, loud noises won't make her so nervous. She deserves a loving and patient home.

description:
******Please note, once completing the initial screen you will be connected with the placement for a video chat. Transports run every few weeks and we will have the dog on the next available transport once approved. If you are not able to accept a dog until a specific time period, please apply at that time************

We are a volunteer run rescue and donate our time to these dogs. IF you are not serious about moving forward in our adoption process, please do not apply. If someone other than yourself is part of the decision making process, please make sure you have spoken with them and they are on board. We really do not want to waste anyone's time if you are not serious about adopting this dog.

Junie B. Jones, 7 years old, spayed female, pitbull/retriever mix, 56 pounds. Junie is located in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of State once an adopter is approved.

Junie B. was saved from a sure euthanasia fate at the local municipal shelter in Houston. We know little about her history prior to arriving at the shelter but it appeared she had been the victim of dog fights/attacks, as she was covered in wounds and scabs.

Since being saved, Junie B. has put in lots of work with our trusted trainer and behaviorist and has done really well with the other dogs at his home. One of his males is her best friend, her "Handsome Warren," if you will. Given her likely history prior to coming into rescue, we would advise Junie have *slow introductions* and time to acclimate to other dogs in the house but she has not been reactive nor does she respond when walking by dogs on a leash. 

Slow introductions typically look like a week spent away from other dogs in a space of their own, followed by "crate and rotate" - passing by the other animals in their crates and being allowed to sniff one another through the barriers. Once successful with passing by crates, introductions progress to being loose on opposite sides of a baby gate; pack walks with limited face-to-face interaction; supervised but still limited face-to-face interaction while all animals on a leash; and finally, loose but monitored interaction off lead.

Junie has been clear: she may be an older gal but she is still a Party Animal - she loves to run and rollerblade, and does extremely well with her handler in these activities. On a typical day, Junie goes on one mile runs with her trainer. She is adamant that your New Year's Resolutions will not falter if she is by your side...call her The Boss of Lunch if you must, but you will get that exercise in no matter what!

Junie has impeccable house manners: she has no issues in a crate and is potty trained, although regression is possible and adopters should be patient with any potential accidents due to disruption in her normal routine & schedule. She walks - and runs, clearly! - well on a leash and rides nicely in a car. She is very friendly to humans and is an overall loving dog, who takes simply stunning photos...so she is sure to quickly become your camera's favorite subject. She is quiet in the house and would love to wiggle into your lap and offer sweet kisses like a Mushy, Gushy Valentine.

We have no history with cats or children, and typically suggest homes with kids over the age of 10yrs, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. Given Junie is now approaching her golden years, we expect she can safely be around younger children with proper introduction and supervision to ensure any unwanted behaviors are addressed ahead of time.

While all of our dogs are special, we believe that Junie B. is the most deserving of a home of Her Own. She would love to be the only dog in your life and has been waiting patiently for her Furever Ever After - will you be the one to show her true love?

***Listed BREED and AGE - We are taking our best guess & recommendations from our veterinarian on age, breed and size when fully grown. We rarely know a dog's exact age nor are we able to tell the true or full breed mix of dogs as our information is limited most of the time. ***

breeds_label: American Bulldog & Pit Bull Terrier Mix
description:
******Please note, once completing the initial screen you will be connected with the placement for a video chat. Transports run every few weeks and we will have the dog on the next available transport once approved. If you are not able to accept a dog until a specific time period, please apply at that time************

We are a volunteer run rescue and donate our time to these dogs. IF you are not serious about moving forward in our adoption process, please do not apply. If someone other than yourself is part of the decision making process, please make sure you have spoken with them and they are on board. We really do not want to waste anyone's time if you are not serious about adopting this dog.

Monty, 3.5 year old, neutered male, pit bull/American bully mix, 59 pounds. Monty is in TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

He was saved from a shelter in San Antonio and has been through so much during his short life - he was found on running the streets underweight, with patchy hair and unsocialized around other dogs. Thanks to his foster instilling lots of foundational work, Monty has proven the resilience of a dog. 

Monty is your standard bully breed - lots of energy and a high play drive. He is neutral to other dogs when first introduced but warms up and really enjoys rough housing and wrestling. He would do best with a submissive pup as he can be rather bossy when it comes to play, but he is confident enough in himself to not require a canine sibling. He's been around male and female dogs and never shown any signs of aggression. 

Monty will require an active home where he will get physical exercise - not just walks but *play* time and mental stimulation - whether that be through training or "brain" games. He really values food and tug, and these have made training more rewarding for him & his foster. He knows sit, touch, place and off, as well as what a 'time out' means (calming down so play can resume). While not a formal heel, Monty knows how to loose leash walk next to you, pulling minimally. Monty responds very well to mild correction and positive reinforcement, so we don't think "formal" training is required to achieve positive behaviors. 

Monty has been around the foster's neighbors' kids (ages 3 and 5yrs) and did well. While they were jumping on the trampoline and having fun, Monty looked to his foster for guidance on how to proceed. We typically recommend home with kids over the age of 10yrs, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. With proper supervision to ensure he doesn't get too animated, we believe Monty can safely be around small children. We have no history with cats.

Monty is fully house trained and has not had any accidents in the home. He is crated when unable to be supervised and now enjoys his kennel, thanks in large part to his foster creating positive associations with the space. Monty should be fed away from other animals as he does tend to resource guard food. He allows his person to handle or remove food but he does not like to share. As a rule of his foster, toys are not left loose in communal spaces. Monty does need a good fence, he can jump anything under 5' and will push under a fence if not secured. 

Like most bully breeds, Monty is very people-oriented and loves human interaction. Overall he is pretty chill but would thrive with a breed experienced adopter willing to put in the time to provide structure and routine, enforce boundaries and additional training. He is very eager to please and catches on quickly.

Anyone should be ecstatic to add this guy to their home and the sky is the limit with him! He has the sweetest demeanor and clearly the most perfect set of ears  either side of the Mississippi.

Lunesta, 6 years old, spayed female, pit bull mix, 55lbs. Lunesta is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Lulu is a sweet, medium energy kind of gal who loves to play. She is in a foster home with a resident pit bull and a shih tzu, and tries engaging them in play. She would love to have a home with a canine companion to play with her. The resident shih tzu will get barky and nippy at Lulu, and she walks away, ignoring him entirely. 

Lulu doesn't have much body awareness and will body check the other dogs when playing or when treats come out. She pushes and shoves to the front of the line for a treat, to get the toy or to be the first one out the door. She can also be quite clumsy, sometimes running into the doors or walls because she is so focused on looking back at you.

Lulu loves to play but also loves to snuggle up and rest with you, or on her own in the crate or on the couch. She is a sweet cuddle bear and enjoys following you around the house ensuring you are never alone nor under attack from an unseen foe. Going to the kitchen? Lulu's coming too. Need to use the restroom? Good idea, she should join you. Headed outside for some vitamin D? Perfect, that is just what she wanted to do also! Not even joking, Lulu really does love the sun and baking as long as you will let her.

Lulu is a toy hoarder. She will sneak and steal the toys from her siblings but is not aggressive of them. As a general rule of the foster, all dogs are fed separately to ensure they eat their own meals but not because anyone resource guards their food.

We have no history with cats but when walking her and she sees one, she wants to charge at it. She has been around children ages 10 and up without issue, and we have no reason to think she couldn't be around very young kids as she's not super jumpy or energetic. Typically recommend a home with kids over the age of 10 years, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues.

Lulu does need to work on her leash manners as she is all over the place and pulls with the typical pittie energy. A harness or Gentle Leader head collar may yield the best results but Lulu's foster has been working patiently with her on this training. Lulu is nearly fully housetrained but will "go" if it has been too long between her potty breaks. She does not have any accidents overnight in her kennel. Lunesta is crate trained and does very well, sleeping and taking her meals in the kennel, as well as being put up when unable to be supervised. 

She would do best in a home willing to help her reinforce the basic manners she already has, ensuring a good solid connection through training and structure. She would enjoy a moderately active house with some walks and fetch opportunities, lots of snuggles and cuddles, and possibly another doggy sibling or two.

Bugs, 8 month old, spayed female, pitbull mix, 20lbs. Bugs is in a foster home in San Antonio, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Bugs was in the city shelter with her sister, Bunny, huddled together in the pre-euth area. We tagged both girls but her sister was adopted before we were able to pick them up, so Bugs has been safe in our care since.

Her nickname is Bugs McCuddles because she doesn’t pass up an opportunity to cuddle or be petted, especially if you are sitting down. She is super sweet and loving toward her humans. Timid with strangers but warms up quickly.  When Bugs gets excited from playing, she sometimes gets “mouthy’ with her foster and tries to nibble her hands or legs. Her foster is working with her with redirection.

Bugs, while initially timid and unsure meeting dogs, lives in a foster home with several resident dogs and plays with all sizes- large, medium, and small (80 lb. Staffordshire Terrier, 45lb Black mouth Cur, 30 lb. Shepherd mix to a 12 lb. Chiweenie). Bugs would do best in a home with another dog of similar age and energy level to continue building her confidence and socialization. 

Bugs plays hard: she enjoys playing chase & tackle, tug of war and with a tethered bungie/rope toy with her foster siblings.  She especially likes to play with stuffed toys that have squeakers, chew her antlers & cow hoofs. She enjoys playing when she wakes up early in the morning and throughout the day but she also really enjoys her naps at all hours of the day. Bugs’ energy when playing is middle of the road/moderate - she is quite chill for being so young.

Bugs is working on her leash walking right now, so she has not had a great deal of exposure to other dogs who are on a leash. Presently, Bugs freezes when we leash her. Super scared, Bugs came to her foster very frightened of everything including people, so even stepping outside took a couple of days. 

Bugs is 50% house broken and is transitioning from pee-pads to going outdoors and communicating her need to go by using bells on the door. Bugs is crated when her foster leaves and for sleeping at night, doing fine. Since she is still young and not yet house trained, Bugs is not left loose in the house while unattended.

Bugs has been around older kids - 12-16 years old - with no issues at all. We believe she would be okay with small children based on her energy level, which is moderate. We have no history of cats.
 
Bugs' ideal home would be a moderately active one with a yard and another dog to play with of similar age and energy level. She will thrive in a home with forever parents who are patient and willing to work through Bug’s fears with her. Forever parents who are experienced dog owners, with a familiarity of rescue pup decompression stages. Bugs wants to be around her humans and cuddle, and she is eager to please.

Dianna, 2yr old, spayed female, pit bull mix, 52lbs. Dianna is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Dianna lives only with her foster mom, so she's not had much socialization around dogs once she was saved from the shelter. Her foster mom has been working to introduce Dianna to other dogs - Dianna has done best outside the house but did get a bit barky and on guard of her home environment when the dog was brought into the house. With time and more experience, we are confident Dianna will be comfortable sharing her home with a doggy sibling. 

Dianna is prototypical pittie - athletic, high energy, fun-loving with lots of playful antics. She loves to romp and roam, jump and play, especially with chew toys. She is very high energy and does best in a harness because she loooooves being outdoors so she tends to pull. Dianna is quite strong, so her foster mom is working hard with Dianna to improve her manners on the leash. 

We have no history with cats. Dianna has been around older kids - ages 10 and 13 years - and done well. We recommend a home with kids 10 years or older, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. Because of Dianna's energy and excitability, she may inadvertently knock over a small child.

Dianna is fully house trained and has only had an accident indoors when  someone isn't paying attention to her signals of needing to go outside. She does really well in the kennel and is fully trained in that regard. Her foster mom crates Dianna when unable to supervise her because Dianna does like chewing on things, including every toy she comes across.
 
Dianna has not shown any issues with toys or treats, but does love to beg for food. She has never met a stranger and loves all people, cuddling when calm and rubbing herself against your legs like a cat. She "corn cobs" when excited, giving little nibble kisses. She is a jumper but Dianna's foster has been working with her on this, too.

Dianna's ideal home would be someone who is breed experienced and is willing to provide structure and routine, putting in time training her. She would do well with a young active couple, who would take her for walks or adventures. She is very loving and wants to please.

Buttercup, 2yr old, spayed female, pitbull mix, 51 pounds. Buttercup resides in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Buttercup was saved from the county shelter and was housed with another dog, and went into a foster home with other pups. She was able to do integrate well but, because of her hearing impairment, she gets startled easily and becomes very defensive when surprised. It is not that she cannot be around other dogs but she needs time to feel comfortable and secure before letting her guard down. To alleviate this, we have found putting up a fence/x-pen and allowing her to see/"meet" the dogs before being let loose with them works best for Buttercup. 

Buttercup has learned some basic obedience using hand signals and tactile marks, and has learned to connect seeing other dogs with a long tap on her right shoulder. Her ideal home would be one who sees her hearing challenges as an opportunity to connect on a deeper level with her and will take the time to train Buttercup, whether on their own or through professional courses.

Buttercup is very human friendly and affectionate. She's a gentle lovebug working to navigate her way through this world with the guidance of her human. She would do best with kids 10 years or older due to her size and hearing issues, which may result in her being startled by young kids. 

Buttercup is a solid 4/10 level dog - she can be playful and excited but her default is to sit back and watch, assess. She is well mannered and doesn't beg, and is overall easy to handle on the leash, with minimal reactivity on walks. She is fully house and crate trained, and enjoys snoozing in bed or riding in a car for adventures.

Kenzy, 2yr old, spayed female, labrador retriever mix, 36 pounds. Kenzy is in a foster home in Houston, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Kenzy and her two siblings were housed at the county shelter when we were notified of the family; while we were working to get plans in place for the whole family, Kenzy's siblings were euthanized. We've since learned that without the comfort and security of another dog, poor Kenzy is unsure how to navigate being in a home environment.

Thankfully, Kenzy is very dog friendly - she loves running around and playing, falling into line with the group with ease - and her ideal home will have a resident dog or established pack. She is still shy and quiet, and needs the assurance from another dog on how to "dog" in this world. 

Kenzy has been in a foster home with many dogs - large and small - and she plays with them all. She is a medium energy girl, she plays until she's done and then goes off to find a quiet place to rest - like under a table. :) While her foster mom works, Kenzy is often found curled up with the other dogs chilling or napping.

Kenzy has exhibited no issues with meeting dogs on/off a leash and walks calmly next to you with only the standard "I'm excited to go out for a walk" pulling. After being in the home for months now, the foster trusts Kenzy to be off leash. She doesn't play much with toys so there have been no issues there, and she has additionally displayed no negative behaviors around food or treats. 

We have no history with cats or kids but given her calm demeanor, we do not anticipate any issues with children. We typically recommend a home with kids aged 10 years or older, or those who can understand and will respect animal behavior cues. Although she does warm up, Kenzy is shy and still uncomfortable with "in your face" affection, so very young children should be supervised around her to ensure she's given time and space. 

Kenzy is crated at night and when unable to be supervised. She feels safe and sometimes prefers going to her kennel for respite, and has shown no separation anxieties or destructive behavior. Kenzy is house and doggy door trained but until she learns the ropes of the house, she may have an accident or two. 
 
Kenzy's ideal home doesn't need to be overly active or work from home but should have a dog or two in the house. She will need someone willing to be patient and allow her to set the pace but giving her the confidence to tackle new things. She is a beautiful sweet girl with a gentle spirit - she just needs time to get used to you. The best way to win over her heart is through her stomach as having treats on hand are a surefire way to lure Kenzy to approach for pets and hellos.

Comet, 2 year old, neutered male, hound/retriever mix, 56 pounds. Comet is in a foster home in San Antonio, TEXAS and can transport out of state once an approved adopter is lined up!

Comet AKA Buddy was saved from the county shelter in San Antonio, having been rescued from the streets with a friend, Essie. Both dogs were saved without plans and have since landed in foster homes! 

Buddy lives in a foster home with another (female) dog. He was initially wary when being introduced but now is very friendly and playful. He has a fairly high but not obnoxious energy level and loves to run the zoomies.  Buddy would love having a canine sibling for companionship. He has a good playstyle and has show no food/resource aggression around the resident dogs.

We have no history with cats or kids, but he will be tested with kids soon. Based upon his behavior to date, the foster has no concerns about his ability to get along well with young children. We typically recommend a home with kids aged 10 years or older, or those who can understand and respect animal behavior cues.

Buddy is fully house, crate and leash trained. He sleeps in his kennel at night and does not whine or cry, and he does not pull on the leash. Since going into foster, he has not had any accidents in the house and will alert you when he needs to go potty. Buddy doesn't appear to have any issues with separation anxiety but is crated when he isn't able to be supervised because his one vice is loving to chew - he's chewed two dog beds so far!

While he has made strong strides in the short time he's been in a foster home, Buddy is still a bit wary of new people but does go to greet them. Having likely been rebuffed while running wild, as soon as Buddy knows he’s not going to be hit/kicked, he opens up.

Buddy's favorite thing is to please, so he has been easy to train and does not require hard corrections. He is very sweet, affectionate and seeks out cuddles, happy to be anywhere with you. He is a resilient and adaptable dog who is looking for his forever buddy!
